newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgian companies want social security tax cut.
newsitem.headline: Belgian companies want social security tax cut.

text.p: Belgian companies should get a cut in social security contributions to compensate for losing tax breaks to exporting companies which are set to be banned by the EU, the Belgian Employers Federation FEB/VBO said on Tuesday.
Earlier European Union Competition Commissioner Karel van Miert said that the Belgian government must reclaim 11.4 billion Belgian francs of illegal state aid it paid to exporting companies.

Under the so-called Maribel II and Maribel III schemes labour-intensive Belgian firms facing foreign competition got exemptions on social security contributions ranging from 25,000 to 37,200 francs per year per worker in the period from 1993 to mid-1996.
"The scrapping of Maribel II and III would handicap us vis-a-vis (companies in) the three neighbouring countries," the FEB said.

"The FEB therefore demands that the government...quickly takes measures to avoid loss of competitiveness. For instance, the introduction of a general Maribel without discrimination...should meet with no resistance from the Commission," it said.
Belgian Prime Minister Jean-Luc Dehaene's spokeswoman declined to comment on Van Miert's statement.
"We will wait for the formal decision by the European Commission on Wednesday, then we will react," she said.
Van Miert said the European Union had no objection to general measures to fight unemployment but that they could not be targeted at exporting firms only.
